node.text:
With seven apartment buildings that are each unique in shape and form, the architecture of our project Nieuw Bergen is as unpredictable as it is exciting. Imaginary planes are drawn from the footprint of neighbouring residential buildings at an angle of 45 degrees, leading to buildings with jagged silhouettes. These ‘suncuts’ allow sunlight to pour into both homes and public spaces. The sloping roofs are ideally suited for solar panels and green roofs, while collective gardens and greenhouses crown a number of buildings - turning the neighbourhood into an urban oasis with plenty of green space for new residents to enjoy.
Of the seven buildings, two are renovations of existing buildings - one from the 1920s and another from the 1950s. All of this makes Nieuw Bergen a shining example of sustainable densification, connecting the traditional with the modern and continuing the informal character of the Bergen neighbourhood.

node.text:
"If you write a book you have only 26 letters and you can write all the books in the world with it. We do that with plants." - Piet Oudolf

In June, famed landscape designer Piet Oudolf visited the construction site of Valley for the first time to watch some of the first plants being added to the "rocky outcrops" on the façade of our building design. Oudolf's planting concept for the project enables a year-round green appearance, with flowering plants turning the publicly accessible terraced valley at the heart of the building into a sensory extravaganza of colours and scents 🌿🌸🐝🌺🪴

Video by wimzagtfilm

node.text:
MVRDV founding partner Winy Maas in conversation with environmental psychologist Joren van Dijk about De Oosterlingen. The project is a block of seven sustainable residential buildings, prominently located at the entrance to Amsterdam's Oostenburg Island, which is a formerly industrial area rapidly developing into a lively residential district. Designed for real estate developer Being, the buildings in the ‘barcode’ composition form a clear family, but each has its own character, with varying heights, roof shapes, and façades made of wood, glass, recycled brick, or biobased composite.

node.text:
Curious what the depot looks like inside? 👀 Join our co-founder Winy Maas for a fun tour of the building in this unique moment, right before the artworks are moved in. 

#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #architecture #design #interior #mirror #reflection #art #depot #boijmans #tour #peep #sneakpeek #film #movie #video #glass #view #rooftop #green #comingsoon #staytuned #rotterdam #netherlands

@boijmans @bambouwtechniek @gemeenterotterdam

Cover image @ossipvanduivenbode
Music composer: Benjamin Tissot / Bensound

node.text:
We're thinking back to the time MVRDVers Klaas Hofman, María López Calleja, and Andrei-Ducu Predescu starred in this very funny advert for @HP laptops 💻🎸🤘 In fact, we've spent much of the last year working away from the office as the advert suggests... but sadly NONE of that time was spent designing rock museums at rock festivals again.

Video by Alex Rigby and @180amsterdam
Ragnarock co-architects: @cobearchitects
Cover image @ossipvanduivenbode

#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #project #architecture #urbanism #design #rock #music #culture #cultural #transformation #funny #video #industrial #festival #public #experience #museum #gold #red #hp #renewal #roskilde #ragnarock #copenhagen #denmark @museumragnarock @roskildefestival @musiconroskilde⁠

node.text:
How does our design for @concordia_design Wrocław find its place in the long and complex history of Słodowa Island? In this video from @story_of_creation by The Making, our co-founder Nathalie de Vries explains how our design will cement Słodowa Island’s reputation as the place to be in Wrocław by engaging creatively with the island's history and working in harmony with its public space.
@concordia_design_wroclaw @demiurg_project @pkob_wegner

Co-architects: @q2studio
Cover image: @juliusz.k.sokolowski
Mural Artist: @alicjabiala

#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #architecture #new #project #building #design #history #transformation #open #public #space #slodowa #wroclaw #poland #video

node.text:
Our exhibition and new office in Berlin are the result of almost 30 years of hard work! In this video produced by PLANE—SITE, our Founding Partner Jacob van Rijs talks about the long journey between his first collaboration with Winy Maas and Nathalie de Vries, the 1991 project Berlin Voids, and the opening of the Berlin office in September. On the way, he gives us a brief glimpse of the archive currently on display at the MVRDV Haus Berlin exhibition, discusses the ideas that drive MVRDV's work, and explains the difference, in his view, between Dutch and German architects.

Video @plane_site
Cover image © Jan Bitter

node.text:
How do you become an architect? What are your ideas about when you design? How do you approach sustainability?
In this 4-episode series from the Almost Not Done Youth program, Dian, Noki, Lis, and Lewis get the rare opportunity to interview Winy Maas on his work, his thoughts about the city, and his latest project Depot Boijmans Van Beuningen.
Check out a preview of the video below and see the full episodes on Almost not done's Vimeo profile:
Episode 1.1 LIS: https://vimeo.com/441836491/1247a2ddb5
Episode 1.2 LEWIS: https://vimeo.com/441842203/b15b294ceb
Episode 1.3 NOKI: https://vimeo.com/441843667/eac1f78937
Episode 1.4 DIAN: https://vimeo.com/441844811/2fe78236ef

@boijmans @almostnotdone
Cover image by @ossipvanduivenbode

We really enjoyed the sweeping shots of the Depot @boijmans Van Beuningen and the life that surrounds it in this video by @onurcantepe. "I wanted to use the camera to explore its qualities, its relation to the public space nearby and its particular materiality. I must say, the boldness of MVRDV looks good on the screen," says Onur. Thanks so much!

node.text:
#MVRDVnext The first episode of our series "Capacity 1.5: Explorations on Contactless Urbanism" is here! 📺 The built environment is based on the scale of the human body, and we all just became 1.5 meters wider. This new normal changes the impact of an individual body and this creates a ripple effect of change through all scales. In the first of eight episodes of "Capacity 1.5" we take a look at the scale of the individual - the you(s) - to understand how changes in our understanding of personal space could impact the future of our planet.
•
•
•
#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #architecture #urbanism #urban #design #research #study #new #series #episode #human #scale #socialdistancing #mvrdvnext #video

node.text:
How can #Reuse help dense cities with tall buildings become sustainable? Our design for the Shenzhen Women and Children's Centre sets an important precedent for repurposing buildings in a city that is soon to see a huge wave of adaptive reuse.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Just a few decades after its initial wave of expansion, many tall buildings in Shenzhen are nearing the end of their initial lifespan. The Shenzhen Women & Children’s Centre is therefore a preview of what could be an emerging trend in the city!⁠
⁠⁠
Our design adds a grid of multi-coloured exterior frames to the existing building that dramatically increases the façade’s depth, providing extra shading to improve the comfort level inside and the thermal performance of the building.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The design also transforms the central courtyard of the building, previously used for car parking, into a public courtyard with outdoor entertainment facilities for children. The access to this inner courtyard is totally barrier-free, making the building a public venue for the city. ⁠
⁠
The roofs of the plinth are used for green outdoor spaces, and are strongly connected with the courtyard, with new external staircases added to allow easy movement between the two, and even a slide to bring some joy to getting around the building.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“Retaining and improving a building is more sustainable than demolishing and building anew, and that is especially true when the building contains as much concrete as this one", explains our founding partner Jacob van Rijs. “It’s an important time to show how great and joyful this approach can be.”⁠ Swipe to see more! 🌿🧸⁠
⁠⁠
#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #project #architecture #tower #library #exhibition #rooftop #hotel #offices #design #interiordesign #renovate #renovation #sustainable # #green #mixed-use #sustainability #recycle #ecological #summer #space #shenzhen #Futian #china #MVRDVreuse⁠

node.text:
#Reuse doesn't only refer to adapting existing structures to new uses - it's also designing with the future in mind! How do we design flexible structures that can accommodate future needs we may not even imagine right now? ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The next phase of the Expo Pavilion’s story builds on the building’s reputation as an important reference for sustainable architecture. Not only will the forest level remain an exemplar of nature in the built environment, it will also become a showcase for the reuse of existing structures, showing how buildings can be designed with future adaptations in mind 🌳⁠
⁠⁠
⁠A key to the design of WERK12 was in the flexibility of the spaces. The building’s extra-high ceilings – with 5.5 metres between each floor – allows for mezzanines or other level changes to be added by future users, for future uses!⁠ 🗯⁠
⁠⁠
When designing the masterplan for Werkstadt Grasbrook, we developed the Grasbrook Maker: a "Serious Game" that presents an interactive platform to playfully explore different possibilities for the future development of the area 🕹⁠
⁠⁠
Our transformation of Museum Schiedam adds a visually clear element, a red shelving system which contains the new programme. Due to its light construction the shelf can be removed at any time without leaving a trace in the historical monument 🏛⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more and check the link in bio!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #project #architecture #urbanism #design #interiordesign #reuse #renovate #transformation #renovation #sustainable #green #culture #retail #educational #environmental #public #space #ExpoPavilion #werk12 #WerkstadtGrasbrook #hamburg #hanover #munich #germany #MVRDVreuse⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸 @dariascagliola , @ossipvanduivenbode

node.text:
Why is architectural #reuse important and how can we redefine our cities by upgrading existing structures? July is #Reuse Month at MVRDV, so let's take a look at projects that transform existing places to activate urban landscapes!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
What do our projects Tainan Spring, Concordia Design and Frøsilo have in common? Although they are located in very different settings, they are all radical transformations whose ultimate aim is to stimulate vibrant urban environments. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tainan Spring is a lush lagoon, bringing more nature to Tainan's busy city centre. Concordia Design establishes a focal point for Sɫodowa Island, making a hub for youth and creativity within the city of Wrocɫaw. Frøsilo changed a former industrial area of Copenhagen into a pleasant, lively residential neighbourhood 🌿⁠
⁠⁠
It is equally important to adapt infrastructural elements to current urban needs. As such, our projects Seoullo Skygarden 7017, Barapullah Springs, and The Hague Canals reimagine these border-creating elements into unifying and vibrant spaces.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Seoullo Skygarden 7017 is not only a pleasant reconversion of a 1960s elevated highway in Seoul - it's a plant library showcasing the country's unique botanical treasure. Barapullah Springs envisages the rehabilitation and renewal of an open sewer in the heart of New Delhi, improving sanitation for vulnerable populations and connecting the city’s neighbourhoods with a comprehensive slow-traffic corridor. The Hague Canals reopens the city's historical network of canals that were filled in during the 20th century, stimulating a lively street culture and green urban mobility 🚤⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more and check the link in bio! ⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
It's #Reuse Month at MVRDV! This July we reflect on the positive environmental impact and creative potential of reuse. Today let's look at reusing materials and building structures!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The Pyramid of Tirana sees the existing brutalist monument dramatically renovated. The concrete structure will be reused and the atrium and its surroundings greened and opened up to accommodate a new educational facility 👩‍💻⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Rather than demolish and rebuild, our design for the Idea Factory sustainably renovates a disused factory building into a “creative factory” with a mixture of offices. At the heart of the design is a public stairway, offering a view to the activities within and leading to a green roof terrace 🌾⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Ragnarock Museum, designed together with @cobearchitects, aims to touch the existing site as lightly as possible to preserve the raw character of the site. The new structure plugs into the factories, while the materials distinguish the old and the new: raw concrete in contrast with vivid red studs ⚡⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠The Roskilde Festival Højskole is housed in a former concrete factory, reusing the original structure’s columns and roof. The design, done with @cobearchitects, is based upon a “box-in-a-box” concept: colourful new modules fill the warehouse-like shell of the main building 📚⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In renovating the historical Stedelijk Museum Schiedam, we designed a visually impactful shelving system, which respectfully meanders around the neoclassical elements - framing them at the same time 🔴⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The new flagship store for lingerie brand Etam renovates a 19th-century Haussmann building by removing internal barriers and adding a glass floor to allow light to fill the interior for a unique shopping experience 🛍️⁠⁠ 

Swipe for more and check the link in bio!
⁠⁠
⁠#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #project #architecture #urbanism #design #interiordesign #reuse #renovate #transformation #renovation #sustainable #green #culture #retail #educational #environmental #public #space #MVRDVreuse⁠⁠
@cobearchitects @the_aadf @piramidatirana @tumocenter @museumragnarock @roskildefestival @musiconroskilde @etam @mvrdvfrance⁠⁠
📸 @ossipvanduivenbode , @dariascagliola , Xia Zhi

Sometimes the most unappreciated parts of our cities have the greatest potential to become transformative, sustainable public spaces! The Grand Blend was our entry in a competition to masterplan the Grand Canal within Tongzhou, which aimed to turn the waterway from a simple piece of infrastructure – used for logistics, sewage, and flood prevention – to a true public space for culture, life, and ecology.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The design naturalises the canal's edges, with soft green riverbanks, small islands, wetlands, and water pools, transforming the canal into an ecological spine through Tongzhou. The variety of programmes provided at the water’s edge is dramatically expanded, with offices and cafés incorporated into the nearby buildings, plazas adapted for various purposes, sports facilities, playgrounds, open-air theatres, markets, and platforms for fishing and birdwatching.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In order to better connect the canal and its new programme to the city, improved routes along and across the canal are crucial. The masterplan’s network of paths is punctuated at three points by major pedestrian bridges connecting key districts of Tongzhou across the canal. The sports bridge incorporates courts for tennis, basketball, and other sports; the event bridge uses a looping ramp to enclose an event plaza; the nature bridge draws a number of interweaving paths into a route through a forest on the water’s edge.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As a project showing how a neglected canal can be transformed into an ecological and social condenser for the city, The Grand Blend is a prime example of how to reprogramme urban areas and infrastructure – one of the four themes of #MVRDVreuse Month! Swipe to see more!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Co-architect China Architecture Design&Research Institute⁠⁠
Visualisations @Atchain⁠⁠
⁠⁠⁠
#Reuse #mvrdv #architects #designers #inspiration#urbanism #architecture #sustainability #sustainable #architecturelovers #architect #architecturephotography #archilovers #green #upcycle #renders #ecological #creative #recycle #nature #plants #inprogress #landscape #sustainability #summer #TheGrandBlend #beijing #北京#china

node.text:
⁠A mixed-use building with a sustainable, pedestrian-friendly design makes a perfect "living room" for an urban area! ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Our project Shenzhen Terraces, which is currently under construction in the Longgang District of Shenzhen, will form the core of a thriving university neighbourhood. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Combining a pedestrian-friendly landscape with no fewer than 20 different programmes including public transport, Shenzhen Terraces is poised to become a sustainable hub for the district area.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The project merges the existing landscape with the new development by using stacked plateaus for its various buildings. The horizontal terraces provide a valuable contrast to the high-rise towers all around, but they also perform an ecological function: overhangs provide shade and the round shape promotes wind flow and natural ventilation. The edges of the terraces dip at strategic points to form connections between the various floors and to double as small outdoor auditoriums.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The landscaping, developed in collaboration with @openfabric, adds patches of jungle-like greenery and public programming between pedestrian routes. These patches host planting that imitates the sub-tropical natural forests of the region, mixed alongside features such as grassy hills, art, pools, and activity zones for climbing or table tennis.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The abundant planting and water features reduce the local temperature and provide habitat for urban wildlife, gardens and rainwater collection generate food and water resources, and photovoltaic panels will adorn extensive portions of the rooftops. The concrete in the building will also be made using recycled concrete, making the project an interesting example in our #MVRDVreuse month! Swipe to see more!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠Swipe to see more! 🌳🌍🌿⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Landscape architects: @openfabric⁠⁠⁠
Renderings: @atchain, Light Studio⁠⁠
⁠⁠⁠

node.text:
What kind of a building results from incorporating sustainability into every surface? Our project LAD HQ in Shanghai is conceived as a "sustainability machine", confronting a wide variety of challenges both indirectly and directly, with high-tech and low-tech solutions.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Through material selection and life-cycle analysis, the embodied carbon of the design will be 40% lower than a typical comparable construction. On the outer walls, the building’s façade is a pleated arrangement of solar panels and glass, angled to protect the interior from strong summer sunlight while allowing winter sunlight into the interiors.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
A series of terraces, clad in wood and covered in greenery, step down to a courtyard and the main pedestrian entrance on the north side. These terraces include a publicly accessible route to the top of the building that provides spaces for the client, agriculture technology company Lankuaikei, to showcase its work and research.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Above the terraces, a swooping technological roof aids in efficient natural ventilation, and supports more solar panels on its southern side. On the northern side, the roof structure is permeable, shading the terraces but allowing water to be collected for use in functions such as toilets. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more! 🌳🌎🌿⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Well-designed outdoor spaces provide more meeting points in the city, thus strengthening local communities! Our project Parkrand condenses housing units into an impressive volume that preserves and even enlarges the park.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The program is split into five towers connected by a lifted semi-public patio that overlooks and enlarges the surrounding park.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The patio offers protection from rain and wind and more intimate spaces and playgrounds. This area becomes a central space for the inhabitants, an outdoor ‘living room’. The soft furniture, decorative walls, ceiling and floor finishes, plants, and ‘chandeliers’ reinforce this cosy atmosphere. Swipe to see more!⁠ 🍃⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Carefully designed outdoor spaces create a strong yet smooth connection between indoors and outdoors! Designed together with @adeptarchitects , Ku.Be House of Culture and Movement is a dynamic meeting point for people of all ages.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The project was designed for the municipality of Frederiksberg as a focal point for both the immediate community and the greater Copenhagen; one that the community could take ownership of and that would adapt based on the specific wants and needs of its users.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The six primary volumes that comprise Ku.Be, distinctive in colour and materiality, each accommodates a unique programme. From the outside, these diverse programmes are hinted at by a fragmented tile façade.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The urban gardens outside form the connection between Ku.Be and its surroundings, playing an important role in expressing the eight volumes and the activities happening inside. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The diverse landscape - a system of microclimates with changing sounds, lights, and scents that blend seamlessly into a hill with integrated slides - reaches out into the gardens and terminates in an outdoor amphitheater. Swipe to see more! 🤸🥏🏃‍♂️⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Comfortable housing is not merely about interior spaces - it's also about the outdoor amenities and landscaping! For our project Future Towers, we imagined a structure resembling a landscape formation, with peaks and valleys, canyons and bays, and grottos and caves. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Its irregular geometry, defined by our extensive research into Indian housing, comprises three distinct blocks, with pedestrian links through the building connecting the adjacent park. A variety of indoor and outdoor amenities and unusual spatial qualities encourage a rich social life to develop, creating a tight community.⁠⁠
⁠⁠⁠
The strong graphical appearance created by the balconies is accentuated by large, brightly coloured openings known as “scoops” that puncture the building’s façade to connect with the central corridor, providing public meeting spaces and cross ventilation in all communal spaces in the process.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The courtyards below are linked by four-storey-high triangular gates, creating a 500-metre-long walk, and also feature different uses, with some designated for play, and others for sport, garden spaces, and more. Swipe to see!⁠ 🍃🎾🤸🏾‍♀️🧘⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
How can we design spaces that stimulate community making? Our project Pixel is a mixed-use development featuring apartments, shops, offices, and amenities situated around a lively communal plaza. The design enables a lifestyle based around outdoor living and community spirit – an innovative approach in the Emirates!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“The values of Makers District – creativity, learning, and sharing – are all at their core about people. So our design creates outdoor spaces with the pedestrian plaza and ‘pixel’ balconies to encourage a sense of community spirit, enabling this social and creative atmosphere”, says our Founding Partner Jacob van Rijs. ⁠⁠
 ⁠⁠
⁠Pixel contains 525 apartments of varying sizes, ranging from studios to spacious three-bedroom homes. These apartments are arranged in a way that celebrates diversity, mixing more expensive units and more affordable spaces together instead of the typical model in which the most expensive units are placed on the highest levels.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The pixelated form of the design also makes the towers wider at the lower levels, making them perfect for accommodating the offices, shops, cafés and restaurants, a clinic, and a wide range of amenities including a pool, gym, community spaces, and a children’s playroom. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The central plaza also forms a part of “The Artery”, a continuous pedestrian public space through Makers District that connects Pixel to the nearby beach. Pixel is currently under construction 🏗️ Swipe to see more!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
A welcoming building makes for an inclusive hub in the city! We're happy to see how the Markthal, completed in 2014, is a central point for the Rotterdam community, inspiring social cohesion, artistic expression, and spontaneous activities. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The Markthal is a sustainable combination of food, leisure, living, and parking, a building in which all functions are fully integrated to celebrate and enhance their synergetic possibilities. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
A secure, covered square is nestled beneath a large arch, conceived as an entirely new take on a typical market square and its surrounding buildings.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
We're thrilled to see how people appropriated Markthal to suit their vision for an inclusive city. @sarfati.philippe exquisitely captured people's interactions with our design in black and white. You can support his beautiful photography project here 👉 https://bit.ly/psterritories⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Markthal's straightforward shape also hides many quirky facts that you probably didn't know about. Head to our Reels to find out more #MarkthalFunFacts!⁠ 💡⁠⁠
⁠⁠
